intro: Tetraena madecassa, commonly known as the Madagascar sandalwood, is a small evergreen shrub native to the island of Madagascar. It belongs to the family Olacaceae and is characterized by its aromatic, woody bark and small, leathery leaves. The plant produces yellowish-white flowers that are typically clustered in small inflorescences. Its seeds are encased in a hard, woody capsule, and the plant is adapted to the dry, seasonal climates of its native habitat. Due to its fragrant properties, it has been historically valued for its use in perfumery and traditional medicine.
